awd_titl_txt: Mechanistic Investigation of CO activation by Nitrogenase
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing sustainable sources of carbon fuels while confronting the accumulation of carbon wastes (CO and CO2) from the combustion of carbon fuels are competing global challenges. With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Markus Ribbe and Professor Yilin Hu from the University of California, Irvine, to investigate the detailed chemical mechanism for how the nitrogenase enzyme reduces CO and CO2 to form larger hydrocarbon compounds. The knowledge acquired through this research informs the design of novel catalysts that recycle carbon wastes into usable fuels, thereby simultaneously combating energy- and environment-related problems. This project provides multidisciplinary education and training across a broad range of experimental and computational techniques to postgraduate researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students. Research and education are integrated through research opportunities across all education levels and through incorporation of microbial biotechnology into classroom teaching. Various outreach events and programs are developed, including Science Saturdays at UC Irvine, to engage middle school students, including those from underrepresented minority communities, to learn about global energy and environmental problems, and potential biotechnological solutions to these problems.

The inability to generate distinct substrate- or intermediate-bound states has remained a major roadblock for mechanistic investigations of nitrogenase. This proposal utilizes a novel approach to uncouple the binding of CO or CO-derived intermediates from the subsequent turnover, thereby providing a unique tool for the generation of successive snapshots along the reaction pathway of CO reduction via controlled delivery of electron(s)/proton(s) to CO or CO-derived species. A strategic combination of chemical, biochemical and spectroscopic approaches will then be used to analyze these defined snapshots in hopes of (1) obtaining insights into the C1 pathway that converts CO to CH4; (2) defining the C1 conformation for the binding and coupling of the second CO; and (3) identifying the mechanism of carbon chain extension.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview: Our world is in dire need of sustainable supplies of carbon fuels; whereas at the same time, it faces the challenge of accumulation of carbon wastes, such as CO (a toxic component in factory or car exhaust) and CO2 (a potent greenhouse gas), which result from the incomplete or complete combustion of carbon fuels. The ability of V-nitrogenase to reduce CO and CO2 to hydrocarbons under ambient conditions suggests the possibility to use this enzyme as a template for future development of effective strategies to recycle the carbon wastes into the usable fuel sources, thereby helping us simultaneously combat the energy- and environment-related problems. Through our studies during the funding period of this project, we have provided mechanistic insights into the enzymatic CO reduction by V-nitrogenase that could inform future designs of novel CO-and CO2-reducing catalysts. As such, our study addresses the fundamental chemistry involved in the function of an important biomolecule, which falls well within the research areas supported by the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) Program.
Intellectual Merit: The inability to generate distinct substrate- or intermediate-bound states of nitrogenase has remained a major roadblock for mechanistic investigations of this important metalloenzyme. Our project utilized novel approaches to uncouple the binding of CO or CO-derived intermediates from the subsequent turnover, thereby providing unique tools for obtaining mechanistic insights into the enzymatic reaction of CO reduction by V-nitrogenase. A strategic combination of chemical, biochemical, and spectroscopic approaches was used to elucidate the mechanism of CO reduction by V-nitrogenase, which is similar to, yet distinct from that of the industrial Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The approaches employed in this research could also be adapted to the generation of other substrate- or intermediate-bound conformations of nitrogenase, such as those related to N2 reduction, which will help unveil the mechanistic details of this crucial reactivity of nitrogenase.
Broader Impacts: The scientific impact of the proposed work can be appreciated from the perspective of the useful products generated by nitrogenase: (i) NH3, a reduced nitrogen source essential for sustaining life on Earth; (ii) H2, a clean energy source important for environmental health; and (iii) hydrocarbons, valuable fuel sources and precursors to important polymers. The fact that nitrogenase is capable of ambient conversion of N2, CO and CO2 to useful products suggests the potential of this enzyme as a template for future development of energy-efficient and environment-friendly strategies to effectively recycle N and C for the benefit of our society. Understanding the mechanism of substrate activation and conversion by nitrogenase, therefore, is crucial for the biotechnological adaptations/applications of this enzyme system, which could address some of the most important challenges our society is facing nowadays. In addition to its scientific impact, our research has broader impacts through outreach efforts, such as Science Saturdays at UC Irvine, which has been hosted by our labs throughout the entire period of this project. Aiming to serve the local SoCal community, Science Saturdays at UC Irvine brings local middle school students to biology and chemistry labs on campus at UCI. Our main goal is to broaden the understanding of science and technology among minorities and the underprivileged kids and to increase their participation in scientific study. The program has been designed by us using NSF guidelines and is headed by our graduate students. Ten events have been completed to date, each with approximately fifty students visiting from Julia Lathrop Intermediate School (JLIS) and Carr Intermediate School (CIS) of the Santa Ana Unified School District. Over 90% of the student population of the Santa Ana Unified School District are Latino/Hispanic, with most of them being first-generation Americans and 95% receiving state-mandated free lunches due to low family income. The students and teachers at JLIS and CIS are particularly interested in this experience because their schools have limited facilities for scientific experimentation, and science classes are often taught with no laboratory component. The overwhelmingly positive comments from the visiting students highlight the positive impact of our outreach efforts on motivating young students, particularly the minority and underprivileged students from the SoCal community, to pursue STEM careers in the future.
